Both the electronic properties and dispersions of the supported Ru catalysts were markedly affected by the nature of the metal oxide support. The specific activity of hydrogenolysis of ethane or propane increased with a decrease in the Ru electron density, but was almost independent of the Ru particle size. The effect of Ru electron density on the specific activity is discussed on the basis of the kinetic mechanism of ethane hydrogenolysis. Introduction The activity of alkane hydrogenolysis over supported transition-metal catalysts is influenced by the metal particle size [1-7], the nature of the support [8], and the catalyst preparation [9]. The influence of metal parti- cle size on ethane hydrogenolysis has been investigated by several groups. The activity of ethane hydrogenolysis on Ni/SiOz-A^Oa increased as the Ni particle size increased [I], while the activity on Rh/SiO; decreased with an increase in the Rh particle size [2]. Recently, Okuhara et al. [6] reported that the activity of ethane hydrogenolysis on Ru/Al203 was almost inde- pendent of the Ru particle size. Thus, different effects of metal particle size on the activity of alkane hydrogenolysis have been reported. This may be attributed to changes in the electronic properties of small metal particles due to metal-support interactions. In a previous communication [10], we reported that the electronic structure of supported Ru catalysts was markedly affected by the nature of the metal oxide support, and that the specific activity of CO hydrogenation increased as the electron density of the Ru particles decreased. In this paper, we report that the specific activity of hydrogenolysis of ethane or propane over Ru-metal oxide catalysts is influenced by the Ru electron density but independent of the Ru particle size. 0304-5102/88/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 124 Experimental Supported Ru catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the metal oxide with Na[Ru3H(CO)u] in methanol solution [11]. The supported catalysts were activated by heating at 400 C for 4 h under vacuum. The content of Ru in the catalysts was 20 mg per g of catalyst. Seven different types of metal oxides were used as supports. SiO; (Davison 952, 350 m2 g~1), 7-A12U3 (Nishio, 150 m2 g~1), MgO (Wako, 93 m2 g~1), and TiOz (Koso, 40 m2 g~1) were pre-treated by heating at 300 - 350 C for 20 h under vacuum. A^O^-SiO^ and MgO-SiO; were respectively prepared by the reac- tions of A1(C2H5)3 and Mg(C2H5)(C4H9) with SiO^ [12], followed by treat- ment with Oa (200 torr) at 500 C for 12 h. TiG^-A^O^ was also prepared by the reaction of Ti(OC4H9)4 with A^O^, followed by treatment with 02 (200 torr) at 500 C. The mole ratios of M:Ru (M = Al, Mg, Ti) in the support catalysts were in the range of 0.8 to 1.9. The dispersions of Ru particles on the supports were determined from the equilibrium amount of H2 adsorption by assuming that one hydrogen atom was adsorbed on each Ru atom on the surface [13]. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of supported Ru catalysts were recorded on a Shimadzu electron spectrometer ESCA 750 with Mg-Ka excitation radiation. Sample preparation for XPS measurements was per- formed in a glove box filled with nitrogen. The C(ls) line (E^ = 284.5 eV) of the adsorbed diffusion pump oil was used as the standard peak. Measured binding energies were reproducible to 0.1 eV. The hydrogenolysis of ethane or propane was carried out at tempera- tures of 130 - 180 C under hydrogen pressures of 50 - 150 torr over the supported Ru catalysts in a closed circulating glass reactor (total volume 230 cm3). The products were analyzed by gas chromatography. Results and discussion The dispersions of Ru particles on metal oxides were determined by H2 chemisorption [13]. From the dispersion the average diameter of Ru particles was calculated by the method of Sinfelt and Yates [14], and is shown in Table 1. Ru dispersion on the A^O^-SiO^ support is the highest among the catalysts prepared in this work. The Ru dispersion on the A^O^- SiC>2 support was almost independent of Ru concentration on the surface in the Ru loading range of 0.5 - 5.0 wt.%, when Na[Ru3H(CO)u] was used as precursor. Therefore, it may be concluded that the Ru dispersion is affected by the nature of metal oxide used as support. As can be seen from Table 1, the binding energy (Ru 3dg/2) of the Ru particles, determined by XPS measurement, is markedly affected by the metal oxide. The binding energies of Ru 3d5/2 are in the range of 279.3 - 280.2 eV, depending on the type of support. The hydrogenolyses of ethane and propane (50 torr) were respectively carried out at 160 and 140 C under H^ (100 torr) over the supported Ru catalysts. The results are given in Table 1. The specific activities, molecules of Cylic, or C3Hg converted into products (CKU from C^H.^, or CH4 and CiHg from C3H8) per surface Ru atom per second, increase as the electron density of Ru particles decreases (see Fig. 1). In contrast, the specific activ- ities are almost independent of the Ru particle size among the Ru-metal oxide catalysts of the same Ru electron density. It is noted that the catalytic activity for alkane hydrogenolysis on Ru particles is mainly regulated by the electronic properties of Ru. As pointed out by Saillard and Hoffmann [18], the breaking of the H-H bond in the H2 molecule on a transition metal surface is accelerated and the equilibrium constant of H2 adsorption increases as the electron density of the metal increases, since the electron transfer from metal to H^ (M -> o* 128 transfer) starts the reaction. A decrease in Ru electron density must make Ha adsorption weak, resulting in a decrease in the value of K^. Lowering the K^ value should increase the specific activity of ethane hydrogenolysis, which is understandable from eqn. (10). However, we have no information concerning electronic effects on the constants K^, K^ and ^4.
